response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the presence of a human subject seated with his arm on a table and the robot arm approaching the region of the neck. The environment is indoor with a solid table surface at the bottom, electronic equipment nearby, and the human's neck exposed for contact. The robot end-effector is near the neck area, presumably at its wrist frame with the three labeled axes (X in red, Y in green, Z in blue). The task requires grasping the neck firmly but gently, then applying massage motions such as kneading, pressing, sliding, and rotating around the neck muscles.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as follows: 
- Wrist +X (red arrow) points roughly to the subject’s right side from the robot’s point of view, aligned approximately horizontally left-right in the scene.
- Wrist +Y (green arrow) points roughly from the neck outward perpendicular to the throat, diagonally upward and toward the subject’s back/side.
- Wrist +Z (blue arrow) points vertically upward relative to the subject’s head and neck.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to vertical motion in the world, either lifting or pressing downward on the neck. Positive wrist Z-axis corresponds to upward motion of the gripper relative to the neck; negative wrist Z-axis corresponds to pressing down toward the neck.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object (neck) must move slightly downward relative to the robot to simulate pressing massage motions, requiring controlled positive and negative forces for firm but gentle pressure.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to lateral sliding motions left-right across the neck surface. Positive X corresponds to sliding from left to right over the neck; negative X corresponds to right-to-left sliding movements.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move with subtle left-right sliding to perform the massage strokes transversely on the neck muscles.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion pushing inward or outward along the neck front-to-back axis. Positive Y corresponds to pushing outward (away) from the neck, negative Y corresponds to pulling inward toward the throat.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must accommodate gentle push-pull motions during massage to stimulate muscles properly with mild compression and release.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object (neck tissue) must be moved in a combination of downward pressing (slight negative Z relative to robot), alternating left-right sliding (X oscillation), and gentle front-back push-pull (Y oscillation). Additionally, mild rotation about the axes, especially Z (vertical) and Y (side-to-side), will contribute to kneading.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck, we consider the following:

- Object Properties: The neck tissue is primarily soft human skin and muscle, deformable and sensitive. The mass of the local neck area engaged is small, around 1-2 kg effective. The tissue offers some compliance and resistance but no rigid joint. Surface friction between the robot end-effector and skin (likely rubberized gripper) is moderately high (~0.6-0.7 static friction coefficient) to prevent slipping during grasp.

- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward on the arm and neck but the neck is supported by the subject’s body. The environment provides stable support but the robot must carefully modulate force to avoid discomfort or injury. Damping arises from soft tissues. No mechanical hinge or joint is involved.

- The relevant object is human neck soft tissue with an estimated mass of approximately 1.5 kg localized at the grasp area, with robot gripper friction coefficient around 0.65 enabling stable grip.

- The surface of interaction is the skin on the neck, slightly moist and soft, with coefficient of friction approximately 0.5-0.7 against the gripping material.

- Contact Types: The robot must maintain a firm but gentle pinch grasp encircling the neck, ensuring contact with multiple contact points around the neck circumference. Surface contact area is soft, increasing contact compliance.

- Motion Type: The task involves combined motion types – pressing downward (negative Z linear motion with force), sliding side-to-side (oscillatory X linear motion), and slight push-pull along Y, along with rotations around Z and Y axes to replicate massage kneading.

- Contact Considerations: Forces must be maintained in X, Y, and Z axes to hold grasp, prevent slip, and provide massage pressures. Additional torque control around axes to rotate the wrist for kneading motions is essential.

- Motion along axes: The robot exerts combined linear motions on wrist X, Y, Z axes and angular torques primarily about Z and Y axes.

- Task duration: A thorough neck massage usually lasts several minutes to allow muscle relaxation and stimulation. Task duration estimated at approximately 120 seconds.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: mass ~1.5 kg; friction coefficient ~0.65; gravity 9.81 m/s²; required grip force sufficient to resist slip plus apply gentle compressive pressure; torque for wrist rotation moderate (≈0.3-0.5 Nm).

- Relevant equations: Force required to maintain grip > (normal force * friction coefficient). Pressing force approximated at ~15 N. Sliding torque based on skin compliance and positional displacement.

- Relevant assumptions: Neck is static except for compliance. The robot wrist has precise force/torque sensing and can modulate force carefully within safe thresholds.

- Computations: Estimated grip force ~20-25 N to ensure no slip, massage pressing force ~15 N, sliding lateral force ~5 N, torque about Z ~0.4 Nm.

- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 1.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.65 along the surface: To maintain grasp and apply massage forces, net force exerted must overcome gravity component (~1.5*9.81 = 14.7 N) plus frictional resistance for sliding motions, confirming force estimates.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon lateral sliding massage needs and friction estimates, the object must exert positive and negative forces (oscillatory) along the X-axis with magnitude approximately 5 N.

Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon push-pull motions along neck inward-outward axis, minor positive and negative forces along Y with magnitude ~3 N are needed.

Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon pressing motions downward on neck, the object must exert negative force along Z (press down) approximately 15 N with intermittent slight upward force for relief (positive force approximately 5 N).

Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon task biomechanics, no significant torque about the X-axis is required (no rolling around lateral axis).

Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon required kneading rotation, clockwise torque of about 0.35 N-m about Y-axis is needed for rotation along neck side axis.

Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon kneading rotational requirements, counterclockwise torque of about 0.4 N-m about Z-axis is required for rotational massage.

Grasping force: Estimated force range is 20 to 25 N sufficient to maintain contact against skin friction and to stabilize the grasp for forceful massage without slipping or discomfort.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human neck soft tissue, approximately 1.5 kg localized mass, compliant, friction coefficient ≈0.65 with robot gripper rubberized surface."

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Oscillatory left-right sliding along X, gentle push-pull along Y, downward pressing and slight relief along Z, with rotational kneading - clockwise about Y and counterclockwise about Z."

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.02, 0.01, -0.01]  # meters stroke magnitude approx for sliding, push-pull, pressing

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [5.0, 3.0, -15.0, 0.0, 0.35, -0.4]  # Newtons, Newton-meters

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 22.0  # Newtons, adequate to maintain contact without slip

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 120.0  # seconds, thorough neck massage duration
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
